support_summary: ATXN3 interacts with the nuclear receptor co-repressor (NCoR1) as part of its role in transcriptional regulation.

functions.cellular_process: ATXN3 acts as a transcriptional corepressor by forming a complex with the Nuclear Receptor Corepressor 1 (NCoR1) and Histone Deacetylase 3 (HDAC3).
functions.effect_description: Normal ATXN3 binds to specific DNA sequences within gene promoters, such as the MMP-2 promoter. This binding facilitates the recruitment of the NCoR1/HDAC3 complex to the chromatin. Once recruited, HDAC3 removes acetyl groups from histones, leading to chromatin condensation and the repression of target gene transcription.
biological_consequence: ATXN3 binds to a specific promoter region on DNA → ATXN3 recruits NCoR1 and HDAC3 to form a repressor complex → HDAC3 deacetylates histones at the promoter → Chromatin structure becomes more compact → Access of transcription factors is blocked → Gene transcription is repressed.
specific_effects: Forms a nuclear repressor complex with NCoR1 and HDAC3.
Recruits the NCoR1/HDAC3 complex to target gene promoters.
Mediates histone deacetylation at specific gene promoters, leading to transcriptional silencing.

evidence.paper_title: Ataxin-3 represses transcription via chromatin binding, interaction with histone deacetylase 3, and histone deacetylation
evidence.relevant_quote: Here we report that normal AT3 binds to target DNA sequences in specific chromatin regions of the matrix metalloproteinase-2 (MMP-2) gene promoter and represses transcription by recruitment of the histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3), the nuclear receptor corepressor (NCoR), and deacetylation of histones bound to the promoter.

evidence.paper_title: Loss of the Spinocerebellar Ataxia type 3 disease protein ATXN3 alters transcription of multiple signal transduction pathways
evidence.relevant_quote: A direct interaction of ATXN3 with HDAC3 and NCoR has previously been established in SCA3 cell lines and human brain extracts yet with only normal (i.e. not expanded) ATXN3 being associated with increased deacetylase activity and repression of gene expression.
